results:
Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the 1951 Disney animated film "Alice in Wonderland" regarding its box office performance and critical reception:

## Box Office Performance

The film was initially considered a box office disappointment, earning an estimated $2.4 million at the US box office in 1951. Despite years of thought and effort, the film met with a lukewarm response at the box office.

The film was never re-released theatrically during Walt Disney's lifetime, airing instead occasionally on network television. However, when Disney gave the film its first theatrical re-release in 1974, promoting it as a film in tune with the "psychedelic" times, this re-release was so successful that it warranted a subsequent re-release in 1981.

## Critical Reception

### Initial Reception
The film received lackluster, even hostile reviews upon its original release, especially in the UK. It was initially considered a critical failure and received generally negative reviews from critics.

Walt Disney was not surprised by the critical reception to Alice in Wonderland – his version of Alice was intended for large family audiences, not literary critics.

### Modern Reception
On Rotten Tomatoes, the film currently has a "fresh" rating of 79% (though some sources cite 84%) from critical reviews with an average rating of 6.6/10. 

The consensus states that "A good introduction to Lewis Carroll's classic, Alice in Wonderland boasts some of the Disney canon's most surreal and twisted images".

### Behind-the-Scenes Criticism
Several Disney animators and staff members were critical of the film:

Animator Ward Kimball felt the film failed because "it suffered from too many cooks – directors. Here was a case of five directors each trying to top the other guy and make his sequence the biggest and craziest in the show. This had a self-canceling effect on the final product".

Animators Frank Thomas and Ollie Johnston considered the film a failure and stated that they felt "none of us could fully capture the characters of Lewis Carroll's imagination".

Even Walt Disney himself was unhappy with the final result.

### Awards
The film was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Scoring of a Musical Picture, but lost to An American in Paris.

### Later Cultural Impact
The film was rediscovered in the early 1970s as a "head film" among college-aged audiences and was shown in various college towns, with Disney initially resisting this association before embracing it with the 1974 re-release.

Over the years, it has been more positively reviewed and is now regarded as one of Disney's best animated films.
